case_vignette: a 66-year-old female with past medical history of right breast cancer treated with radiation presents with a slowly growing mass on the right breast. she states the spot initially began as a small bruise then progressively enlargened over the past few months and now spontaneously bleeds. examination reveals a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule on the right breast. an excisional biopsy reveals atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.
question: What is the final diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I have a slowly growing mass on my right breast that initially looked like a small bruise, and now it has gotten bigger and started bleeding on its own.
How long have you had this mass and how has it changed in size over time?
The mass has been growing over the past few months. It started as a small bruise and then progressively enlarged.
Do you experience any pain or other symptoms associated with the mass?
No, I don't experience any pain with the mass.
Have you had any previous medical issues related to breast disease or any family history of breast cancer?
I have a past medical history of right breast cancer which was treated with radiation.
Do you have any history of undergoing any surgeries for breast cancer?
I did not mention undergoing surgery for breast cancer, only radiation treatment.
Have you noticed any changes in the skin over the mass, such as puckering or dimpling?
No, I have not noticed any puckering or dimpling, but the mass is a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule.
Have you undergone any biopsy or investigation on this new lesion?
Yes, I had an excisional biopsy done on the lesion.
What was the result of the biopsy?
The biopsy revealed atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.
**Final Diagnosis:** Angiosarcoma of the breast.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient reports a slowly growing mass on her right breast, which initially appeared as a small bruise and has now increased in size and started bleeding spontaneously. The growth of the mass has been observed over the past few months, beginning as a small bruise and then progressively enlarging. The patient denies experiencing any pain associated with the mass. She has a past medical history of right breast cancer treated with radiation but mentions no surgical interventions for breast cancer. The patient has not observed any signs of puckering or dimpling of the skin around the area, but describes the mass as a violaceous, red exophytic thick nodule. An excisional biopsy of the lesion has already been performed. The biopsy results indicated atypical pleomorphic endothelial cells lining ill-defined vascular spaces and prominent hemorrhage.
